name: 1w
description: White to move, mate in one.

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Qd8 mate. Thanks to Rick Botto for pointing out Qe6 mate also.
1. Bd5 wins the rook on a8.
1. g4 traps the knight on h5
1. Nb5+ wins the rook on d4.
1. d6 traps the bishop on d6
1. g3 wins the bishop on h2.
1. Qe4+ wins the Queen on b1
1. Nd7 forks a rook and queen
1. Ke4+ or Ke2+ wins the rook
1. Rxe8+ wins the Queen on g8!
1. Re4+ wins the knight on e6.
1. Qf6+ forks the king and rook

parsed_solution: 1. Nd5!! uncovers an attack on the queen wich has no safe square to move to.

parsed_solution: White may still be lost, but he should at least play 1. Nb6 forking the two rooks

parsed_solution: 1. Qxc5 black resigns! Note that the pawn on d6 is pinned to the queen by the rook on d1

parsed_solution: 1. Kf2 wins because he is attacking the rook on e3 and the bishop on b7 at the same time.

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Ne6 forks the Queen and Rook (although the position is complicated, white should win.)
parsed_solution: 1. Ne6 forks the Queen and Rook (although the position is complicated, white should win.)

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Bf4 skewers the Black Queen to the bishop on d6 which is already attacked by the queen on d1.
parsed_solution: 1. Bf4 skewers the Black Queen to the bishop on d6 which is already attacked by the queen on d1.

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Nd6+ or Nf6+ uncovers an attack on the queen. Thanks to Vince Deuel for surprising me with this one.
parsed_solution: 1. Nd6+ or Nf6+ uncovers an attack on the queen. Thanks to Vince Deuel for surprising me with this one.

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Nd6+ creates a discovered attack on the queen at d5 by the queen on f3. So the queen is lost
parsed_solution: 1. Nd6+ creates a discovered attack on the queen at d5 by the queen on f3. So the queen is lost

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Ne6 mate. Moving the knight elsewhere does not work because black can play Bd7. The double check mates this work.
parsed_solution: 1. Ne6 mate. Moving the knight elsewhere does not work because black can play Bd7. The double check mates this work.

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Nc4 attacks the Queen and Bishop. Since the Bishop is also attacked by the bishop on f4, it will drop next move.
parsed_solution: 1. Nc4 attacks the Queen and Bishop. Since the Bishop is also attacked by the bishop on f4, it will drop next move.

puzzles.unparsed_solution: The correct way is 1. Qa4+ with a fork on the knight. The wrong way would be 1. Nxe5 (Hoping to play Qa4+ next move) Qa5+ refutes this idea.
parsed_solution: The correct way is 1. Qa4+ with a fork on the knight. The wrong way would be 1. Nxe5 (Hoping to play Qa4+ next move) Qa5+ refutes this idea.

puzzles.unparsed_solution: 1. Nxe5+ wins the rook on c6. It is a little more complicated than that though. If Black responds 1. ... Ke7 then both Rxc6 and Nxc6 win.
parsed_solution: 1. Nxe5+ wins the rook on c6. It is a little more complicated than that though. If Black responds 1. ... Ke7 then both Rxc6 and Nxc6 win.
